meta_data.title: What is Life By the Spirit and How Do I Do That? Or Am I Asking the Wrong Question?
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 5:16-18 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, everybody, it's Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast. We're doing something weird this week. We're working on a challenging high stakes for you and me passage in Galatians 5, specifically it's Galatians 5, 16, which says, so I say live by the spirit and you will not gratify the desires of the sinful nature. Other translations say the indulged the flesh. And I got my buddy Jeff here working it through with me all week. So we're just going to pick up where we left off yesterday. But I think the thing they're all sitting here wondering now is, okay, so what do I do? Don't do these things. Got it. But how do I move forward? And we're getting into stuff that is that it feels like is almost not do oriented. And that's, I think, a little bit confusing. And it's understandable who would take a minute for people to figure out what Paul's driving it. Yeah. And we can wrap ourselves around the axle on what does flesh mean, but we would lose the main point, which is his answer to your question. Okay, then what do we do? And his answer is live by the spirit. Live by the spirit. That's the answer. Honestly, it was kind of a profound thing for me to realize maybe about 10 years ago that the real Christian life wasn't the Christian doing more religious things to try and keep God happy. It was connect with the spirit and let the spirit do the work. It's in the Bible everywhere, but I didn't see it. Why do you think you missed it? I kind of passed over Holy Spirit stuff for a long time because I was, I don't know, scared of some of the extremism maybe that I saw. Some of it's worth being scared of. But I wasn't looking into this because I had this weird experience that I couldn't place. It was more like, if the Bible says it, why can't we build a understanding of the Holy Spirit and then just like live there? Because the more I studied, the more I realized the Holy Spirit's role in the sanctification of a follower of Jesus is like on every page, dude. It's like everywhere. Like what? Well, there's that big prophecy from Ezekiel about, I will take from them their heart of stone and give them a heart of flesh and I'll put my spirit in them and I'll cause them. I'll make them obey me. So it's that internal change from the spirit as opposed to external change from behavior. The one that was huge for me was 2 Corinthians 3 where Paul's talking about when Moses had to wear a veil because of the glory of God, reflecting off him too much to the Israelites and the wilderness. But now we don't have a veil with unveil faces. We can behold his glory and that glory is transforming us from one degree to the next. And this is what the Holy Spirit does. Like, that's my paraphrase, but essentially that's the teaching. And again, it's the experiencing of God in his fullness that we now can do because of the spirit and through the spirit. That's what transforms us. What is it? John 15, the vine in the branches, right? The abiding in Jesus. That whole section is about the Holy Spirit and 14, 15 and 16. Jesus is talking about the spirit. Like he's like, if I go away, it's actually better for you because then you can have the spirit and they don't quite understand that. I'm not sure I really understand that yet either, but is it better for me? And if it is better for me, how? But by the spirit, I can abide and then he bears the fruit instead of me working really, really, really hard by human effort to bear the fruit, which I think is what's going on in Galatians 5. But those are just some examples of like, this is what the spirit does. So when it says walk by the spirit and you won't do the flesh stuff, like I think it means set your mind on those truths of the spirit or get to know the spirit, spend time with the spirit. So if that's like the disciplines, but like trust him, not yourself. Yeah. And even when it's good, that's intimidating. Right. Because we can't quantify it. No, nor control it. Yeah. And I think that's Paul's point. We so much, we want to put rules and regulations and boundaries so we can measure these things. And I think the verses we're about to get to at the end of chapter five really show the only way to really measure any of this is by the fruit. So then you get this language. The NIB says, so I say live by the spirit. The ESV English standard version is a little more descriptive, a little more artful walk by the spirit and it takes my brain to first John, the one you memorized at camp. If we walk in the light is he's in the light. Well, I fellowship with one another in the blood of Jesus, his son purifies us from all sin. Act 17 for him. We live and move and have our being that just the idea that it is that it's all inclusive that the Christian life that is dependent on God, the life by the spirit that Paul is saying, this is the ideal. This is the opposite of what the Judaizers and the agitators, the pro circumcision crowd. This is the opposite of what they've been telling you. It's life by the spirit. All of that stuff does feel a little bit out of control and like it happens really apart from effort. And it's very disorienting because nothing good happens apart from effort. Not in our understanding. Well, it's not that effort's not in play. It's trusting in the effort and the works of the human to accomplish any of this. I mean, we don't sit in faith. We act in faith. We walk in faith. But those actions and walking aren't based on our own ability to sanctify ourselves. It's by faith in the power of God to do the sanctifying work as we walk. Or how about this? Bible quiz. Let's see how much you remember from camp. How many times did the people walk around Jericho? Seven times the day that the walls fell down. Okay. So seven times they did a lap the six days before each. So one, one each day before. Okay. So 13 total times. Here's a million other question. What made the walls fall down? God. God. So had they only marched around at four times, would it have still worked? No. Well, I don't know. I don't remember well enough. What was the command specifically to Joshua? Well, what they did wasn't it was the command. What they did wasn't that exactly what they were told to do. Yeah. So here you have a great case and there's dozens of them that you and I could rattle off. I'm sure where the people obeyed by walking, but it was God who did the work. Okay. So there is this combination throughout scripture where we walk God works. So who gets the credit? Well, God does because he's the one doing it. Could he do it without us walking? Sure. I agree with your point. I need to amend my earlier statement though because just a little bit before that incident in the Old Testament, Moses did not obey the protocol and water still came out. Right. And what happened to Moses? He died looking at the land that had been promised to his people and didn't get to go in. Yeah. And I think it's another great data point of obedience from the flesh versus obedience from trusting God. The obedience of the people puts them into the powerful working of God and their obedience merits nothing because it's God who did all the work. I totally agree with that as a biblical principle. I'm not sure I totally agree that's what Galatians 5, 16 through the end of the chapters is saying though. Well, no, but you had asked, okay, what do we do? Right. And I think the way I do it in my head or in my heart, I guess, is this we walk God works and I can walk by the spirit or I can walk by the flesh. I mean, Paul says it pretty explicitly in Ephesians 2. It's by grace you've been saved through faith. This is not of yourselves. It's a gift from God so that no one can boast. But then he goes on, right? And it's like you now are God's workmanship and you're created in Christ Jesus to do good works that God has prepared in advance that we should walk in them. So the good works really are us walking because God has made us new from the inside out. As opposed to we do the good works to be transformed from the outside in because if that was the case, then we would have a reason to boast because like I did the thing. So I'm cool. Yes, I can't argue with that. And yes, if anything good or redemptive happens at all, God gets credit for that. But also on God commands us not to do stuff and to do certain other things. So it feels like I'm picking and it feels like there are two wolves is my point. You're making the argument and I think you're making it well that the spiritual reality may be a little more complex or maybe a little more simple, depending on how you frame it than the way it feels to me. For example, it feels to me like I have complete and total free will like I can do anything I want to do right now. But I don't have complete and total free will because I can't not sin. I can't just turn that faucet off and never sin again. It doesn't matter how much I will to do that. I will then turn around and will or accident my way into having done it again. And also there's language in the Bible indicating that somehow at least sometimes God picks even though it feels like I always pick. So sometimes I run into stuff in the Bible that's difficult because the text describes a spiritual reality that makes sense to me given that God is omni everything and infinitely everything. But then my lived experience from my finite position feels a little different than that from my perspective. And this is one of those places where I think the two wolves interpretation of this passage, it works because it squares with our lived reality. It feels like there are two things that war within me. It feels like they they vie for my attention. It feels like I can kind of get on a roll on the good stuff. It feels like I can kind of get on a roll on or on a slide on the destructive stuff. So then given that that's how things feel, I get to this passage that is describing a larger spiritual reality. And I just instantly map over the top of it how things feel whether that's exactly what's being talked about here or not. I totally get everything you just said. And I disagree on one point, but I think it's a key point that will help us get to where we're going, which is I think because of the Holy Spirit, you can not sin. Whereas before you could not not sin. Hey, this is future Jeff interrupting past Jeff and past Matt to say we have one more of these episodes from our conversation. And thank you for listening in and being a part of it. And then we will be back to the next passage in Galatians and your regularly scheduled fart jokes and weird outro music. This has been the 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
